titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the William Julius Mickle Papers
titlestmt.author: by Diane J. Ducharme and Thanh Tran

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 04:37

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The William Julius Mickle Papers document aspects of the literary and naval careers of William Julius Mickle. The collection includes correspondence from literary figures such as William Ballantyne, William Bowles, David Garrick, Francis Gentleman, Isaac Reed, and John Sim, and from family friend and naval patron Commodore George Johnstone; manuscripts of several works by Mickle, including The Concubine and The Death of Socrates; and papers relating to Mickle's service as prize agent for Johnstone's naval squadron.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased by James Marshall Osborn from Sotheby's (21 May 1968 sale), 1968. Bequest of James Marshall Osborn, 1976.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: From the collection of T. M. Ellis.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The William Julius Mickle Papers are the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: William Julius Mickle Papers. James Marshall and Marie-Louise Osborn Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was arranged and cataloged by curatorial assistants in the 1970s and 1980s. Further rehousing and description were carried out in 2010. Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and compiled from individual catalog cards.

bioghist.head: William Julius Mickle,1734 or 1735-1788.
bioghist.p: William Julius Mickle (1734 or 1735-1788), was born William Meikle in Scotland and inherited his father's Edinburgh brewery in 1757. After it failed financially in 1763, Mickle secretly moved to London, changed the spelling of his last name, and embarked on a literary career. He was corrector for the Clarendon Press, Oxford, from 1765 to 1772. Mickle's first success was the neo-Spenserian poem The Concubine (1767).

From 1772 until 1779 he lived with a patron, Robert Tomkins of Forest Hill, and attempted to earn his living solely as an author. He repeatedly rewrote his verse tragedy, The Seige of Marseilles , in the hopes of seeing it performed, but the London theater managers repeatedly refused to stage it. His other ambitious project was more successful: his verse translation of Luís de Camões's epic poem Os Lusíadas (1572) was published by subscription in 1776 as The Lusiad, or, The Discovery of India . While Mickle's command of Portuguese was questionable, the work earned him almost a thousand pounds and remained the standard translation of this national epic for almost a century.

Mickle, however, was still burdened with old debts, and in 1779 his patron Commodore George Johnstone appointed him purser of the HMS Brilliant . Johnstone's squadron was stationed in Portugal, and the Portguese welcomed the translator of their national poet, electing Mickle to the Academia Reale. His naval career was a success; in 1780 he was appointed prize agent for the squadron, which improved his fortunes enough for him to marry Mary Tomkins, daughter of Robert Tomkins, in 1782. The couple moved to Wheatley, Oxfordshire, where Mickle spent much time revising his works. He died after a short illness in 1788 and was survived by his wife and his son, Charles Julius Mickle.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The William Julius Mickle Papers document aspects of the literary and naval careers of William Julius Mickle. The collection includes correspondence from literary figures including William Ballantyne, William Bowles, David Garrick, Francis Gentleman, Isaac Reed, and John Sim, as well as from family friend and naval patron Commodore George Johnstone; manuscripts of several works by Mickle, including The Concubine and The Death of Socrates ; and papers relating to Mickle's service as prize agent for Johnstone's naval squadron in the early 1780s.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: I. Correspondence, 1753-1825. II. Writings, 1762-1774. III. Naval Papers, 1780-1789.

controlaccess.subject: Authors, English -- 18th century
English drama -- 18th century
English poetry -- 18th century
Prizes (Property captured at sea) -- Great Britain

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Alphabetically arranged by correspondent. Letters from Mickle to other recipients are filed under "Mickle, William Julius."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence consists primarily of letters received by William Julius Mickle, mostly concerning literary matters. Major correspondents include the authors William Bowles, Francis Gentleman, David Price, and the book collector and scholar Isaac Reed. Letters from William Ballantyne and João Jacinto Magalhães discuss Mickle's translation of Os Lusiadas (The Luciad) . An undated letter by David Garrick offers the young poet advice, while a 1769 letter contains criticism of The Siege of Marseilles .

The letters of Commodore George Johnstone contain personal and family news as well as information relating to Mickle's service in the Royal Navy. Some of the letters by Mickle, located in folders 89-105, also concern naval affairs and prize money.

did.unittitle: Lyttelton, Lord (verbatim copy of letters to and from)

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Alphabetically arranged by title of work, with untitled material at the end.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contents include drafts of The Concubine and The Death of Socrates . The devotional essays at the end of the series are mostly incomplete.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Notebook also includes draft of Count Chateaubriant , an early version of The Siege of Marseilles .

did.unittitle: The Death of Socrates, a Masque : holograph
The Siege of Marseilles : proof fragment

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Naval Papers includes letters of petition for prize money addressed to Mickle in his capacity as prize agent for Commodore Johnstone's squadron; copies of notes and memoranda; and a drawing of the squadron at anchor in a bay.
